block.p: Warren Buffett Faithful In Their Annual Pilgrimage With the stock of Berkshire Hathaway on the rise again after taking a beating in the last year, shareholders came to his annual meeting over the weekend willing to grant him some vindication.

Some suggested he should pep up his portfolio by venturing into technology, but Mr. Buffett said no. That was fine with many other shareholders who said they considered their Berkshire shares to be the conservative part of their portfolio. [Page C8.]

MP3.com Hopes for Settlement The online music service MP3.com is guardedly confident that it can reach a settlement with the Recording Industry Association of America to allow the company to continue operating. A federal court ruled on Friday that MP3.com violated copyright law by creating an online database of major-label recordings. [C6.]

Online Retailers Review Spending Now that they're focusing on attracting customers rather than investors, many Internet retailers are reconsidering their spending for good placement on Web portals, posing a threat to the income of companies like Yahoo, Excite and America Online. [C10.]

Panel Plans New Internet Suffixes Armed with a formal but vague go-ahead from one of its advisory panels, the Internet's international oversight body has begun writing a plan for new suffixes that would be added to ones like .com, .net and .org. [C6.]

Excite Develops a Mobile Service Excite@Home plans to announce that it has developed a version of the Excite Web portal for mobile applications like cellular telephones in an attempt to catch up with Yahoo. [C6.]

Finding Value in the Old Economy Maxager, a company that helps other companies do business on the Internet, is looking for employees who are conversant in technology, but not the technology of computer-speak and not if they have funny hair and nose rings. Maxager and other companies are starting to value employees who understand old-fashioned things like inventory management. [C4.]

European Telecom Merger Possible Royal KPN, the largest telephone operator in The Netherlands, is in talks with Telefonica SA of Spain about merging their mobile telephone operations in an effort to create a pan-European mobile network that could compete with the likes of Vodafone Airtouch P.L.C., the world's largest mobile operator. [C14.]

Mattel Paid Ex-Chief $37 Million Mattel gave its former Chief Executive Jill Barad a severance package worth more than $37 million after she resigned in February, the company said in a government filing. [C14.]

A Lesson in Big-Time Marketing Two years after persuading the National Basketball Association and Michael Jordan to cooperate on an IMAX film that chronicles the life of Michael Jordan, two brothers who are producing it are getting a lesson in big-time sports marketing. Advertising. [C16.]
